xxl.core.cursors.sources

Class ArrayCursor<E>

  • java.lang.Object
    • xxl.core.cursors.AbstractCursor<E>
      • xxl.core.cursors.sources.ArrayCursor<E>
  • Type Parameters:
    E - the type of the specified array's components.
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    Iterator<E>, Cursor<E>

    public class ArrayCursor<E>
extends AbstractCursor<E>
    An array-cursor constructs a cursor backed on an arbitrary object array. The elements from a user-defined array (array[0] to array[array.length-1]) will be returned by the array-cursor. Note, that the order can also be user-definded when the caller specifies a further iteration indices defining the order the elements will be returned.

    Example usage (1): 

       Object[] numbers = Cursors.toArray(new Enumerator(5));
     
   ArrayCursor<Object> arrayCursor1 = new ArrayCursor<Object>(numbers);
 
   arrayCursor1.open();
 
   while (arrayCursor1.hasNext())
       System.out.print(arrayCursor1.next() + "; ");
   System.out.flush();
   System.out.println();
 
   arrayCursor1.close();
    At first this example converts an enumerator with the elements 0,...,4 to an object array using the static method Cursors.toArray(java.util.Iterator). This object array called numbers is given to the second constructor of this class and a new instance of an array-cursor is generated. This array-cursor is completely consumed in the while-loop and at last it is closed. So the output is: 
       0; 1; 2; 3; 4;

    Example usage (2): 

       // using an indices iterator
 
   ArrayCursor<Object> arrayCursor2 = new ArrayCursor<Object>(
       numbers,
       new Enumerator(4, -1)
   );
 
   arrayCursor2.open();
 
   while (arrayCursor2.hasNext())
       System.out.println(arrayCursor2.next() + "; ");
   System.out.flush();
   System.out.println();
 
   arrayCursor2.close();
    This example creates a new instance of an array-cursor using the above defined enumerator and further an iteration of indices, given to the constructor, implemented as an other enumerator containing the elements: 
       4; 3; 2; 1; 0.
    According to the order the iteration of indices defines, the output is reversed.

    See Also:
    Iterator, Cursor, AbstractCursor

    • Field Detail

      • array

        protected E[] array
        The object array holding the data to be returned by the array-cursor.

      • indices

        protected Cursor<Integer> indices
        An iteration of indices defining the order the elements stored in the object array will be returned by the array-cursor. If such an iteration of indices has not been specified a simple enumerator holding the indices 0,...,array.length-1 is used instead, i.e., the data is returned in the same order as it is contained in the object array.

      • index

        protected Integer index
        The current position of this iteration in the object array.

    • Constructor Detail

      • ArrayCursor

        public ArrayCursor(Iterator<Integer> indices,
                   E... array)
        Creates a new array-cursor. The elements stored in the given oject array will be returned according to the order given by the iteration of indices.
        Parameters:
        array - the object array delivering the elements of the cursor.
        indices - an iteration of indices; the indices of this iteration define the order the elements will be returned by the array-cursor.

      • ArrayCursor

        public ArrayCursor(E... array)
        Creates a new array-cursor. The elements from array[0] to array[array.length-1] will be returned by this array-cursor. The order will be specified by a new enumerator, i.e., the elements are returned in the same order as they are contained in the given object array.
        Parameters:
        array - the object array delivering the elements.

    • Method Detail

      • hasNextObject

        protected boolean hasNextObject()
        Returns true if the iteration has more elements. (In other words, returns true if next or peek would return an element rather than throwing an exception.)
        Specified by:
        hasNextObject in class AbstractCursor<E>
        Returns:
        true if the array-cursor has more elements.

      • nextObject

        protected E nextObject()
        Returns the next element in the iteration. This element will be accessible by some of the array-cursor's methods, e.g., update or remove, until a call to next or peek occurs. This is calling next or peek proceeds the iteration and therefore its previous element will not be accessible any more.
        Specified by:
        nextObject in class AbstractCursor<E>
        Returns:
        the next element in the iteration.

      • update

        public void update(E object)
            throws IllegalStateException,
                   UnsupportedOperationException
        Replaces the last element returned by the array-cursor in the underlying object array (optional operation). This method can be called only once per call to next or peek and updates the element returned by this method. Note, that between a call to next and update the invocation of peek or hasNext is forbidden. The behaviour of an array-cursor is unspecified if the underlying object array is modified while the iteration is in progress in any way other than by calling this method.

        Note, that this operation is optional and might work for all cursors

        Specified by:
        update in interface Cursor<E>
        Overrides:
        update in class AbstractCursor<E>
        Parameters:
        object - the object that replaces the last element returned by the array-cursor.
        Throws:
        IllegalStateException - if the next or peek method has not yet been called, or the update method has already been called after the last call to the next or peek method.
        UnsupportedOperationException - if the update operation is not supported by the array-cursor.

      • supportsUpdate

        public boolean supportsUpdate()
        Returns true if the update operation is supported by the array-cursor. Otherwise it returns false.
        Specified by:
        supportsUpdate in interface Cursor<E>
        Overrides:
        supportsUpdate in class AbstractCursor<E>
        Returns:
        true if the update operation is supported by the array-cursor, otherwise false.

      • reset

        public void reset()
           throws UnsupportedOperationException
        Resets the array-cursor to its initial state such that the caller is able to traverse the underlying object array again without constructing a new array-cursor (optional operation). The modifications, removes and updates concerning the underlying object array, are still persistent.

        Note, that this operation is optional and might not work for all cursors.

        Specified by:
        reset in interface Cursor<E>
        Overrides:
        reset in class AbstractCursor<E>
        Throws:
        UnsupportedOperationException - if the reset operation is not supported by the array-cursor.

      • supportsReset

        public boolean supportsReset()
        Returns true if the reset operation is supported by the array-cursor. Otherwise it returns false.
        Specified by:
        supportsReset in interface Cursor<E>
        Overrides:
        supportsReset in class AbstractCursor<E>
        Returns:
        true if the reset operation is supported by the array-cursor, otherwise false.
